slides.title: Inferential Statistics Overview
slides.content:
# Inferential Statistics ğŸ“Š

Making conclusions about populations from samples.

## What You'll Learn
- **Sampling Methods** - How to collect representative data
- **Confidence Intervals** - Quantifying uncertainty
- **Central Limit Theorem** - Foundation of inference
- **Estimation Theory** - Point and interval estimates

> ğŸ’¡ **Key Insight:** We rarely have access to entire populationsâ€”inference lets us draw valid conclusions from samples!

## Descriptive vs Inferential

| Type | Question | Example |
|------|----------|--------|
| Descriptive | What does the data show? | Average height is 170cm |
| Inferential | What can we conclude about the population? | Population average is between 168-172cm |

## The Inference Process

```
Population â†’ Sample â†’ Statistic â†’ Inference â†’ Population
   (?)       (known)   (calculated)  (estimate)    (conclusion)
```

## Applications

- ğŸ—³ï¸ Election polling
- ğŸ’Š Clinical trials
- ğŸ“ˆ Market research
- ğŸ­ Quality control

Let's learn to draw valid conclusions! ğŸ¯

slides.title: Population vs Sample
slides.content:
# Population vs Sample ğŸ¯

Understanding these concepts is fundamental.

## Definitions

**Population:** The entire group you want to study
- All customers of a company
- All adults in a country
- All products manufactured

**Sample:** A subset of the population
- 500 surveyed customers
- 1,000 polled voters
- 100 tested products

## Parameters vs Statistics

| Concept | Population | Sample |
|---------|------------|--------|
| Term | Parameter | Statistic |
| Mean | Î¼ (mu) | xÌ„ (x-bar) |
| Std Dev | Ïƒ (sigma) | s |
| Proportion | p | pÌ‚ (p-hat) |
| Known? | Usually unknown | Calculated |

## Why Sample?

- âœ… **Cost:** Studying everyone is expensive
- âœ… **Time:** Faster than census
- âœ… **Practicality:** Sometimes destructive testing
- âœ… **Sufficient:** Good samples give accurate estimates

## Key Principle

> ğŸ¯ **Goal:** Use sample statistics to estimate population parameters with quantified uncertainty!

slides.title: Sampling Methods
slides.content:
# Sampling Methods ğŸ²

How you sample determines the validity of your conclusions.

## Probability Sampling

### Simple Random Sampling
Every member has equal chance of selection
```python
import numpy as np
np.random.seed(42)
population = list(range(1, 1001))
sample = np.random.choice(population, size=50, replace=False)
```

### Stratified Sampling
Divide into groups, sample from each
- Ensures representation of subgroups
- Example: Sample by age groups

### Cluster Sampling
Randomly select groups, study all in selected groups
- Example: Select random schools, survey all students

### Systematic Sampling
Select every kth element
- Example: Every 10th customer

## Non-Probability Sampling

| Method | Description | Risk |
|--------|-------------|------|
| Convenience | Easiest to reach | High bias |
| Volunteer | Self-selected | Selection bias |
| Quota | Fill predetermined quotas | May miss groups |

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
import numpy as np

np.random.seed(42)

print("=== Sampling Methods Demo ===")

# Population
population = np.arange(1, 1001)
print(f"\nPopulation size: {len(population)}")

# Simple Random Sampling
print("\n1. SIMPLE RANDOM SAMPLING")
srs_sample = np.random.choice(population, size=50, replace=False)
print(f"   Sample size: {len(srs_sample)}")
print(f"   First 10: {srs_sample[:10]}")
print(f"   Sample mean: {np.mean(srs_sample):.1f}")
print(f"   Population mean: {np.mean(population):.1f}")

# Stratified Sampling (simulated)
print("\n2. STRATIFIED SAMPLING")
low = population[population <= 333]
mid = population[(population > 333) & (population <= 666)]
high = population[population > 666]

strat_sample = np.concatenate([
    np.random.choice(low, size=17, replace=False),
    np.random.choice(mid, size=17, replace=False),
    np.random.choice(high, size=16, replace=False)
])
print(f"   Sample size: {len(strat_sample)}")
print(f"   Sample mean: {np.mean(strat_sample):.1f}")

# Systematic Sampling
print("\n3. SYSTEMATIC SAMPLING")
k = 20  # Every 20th element
start = np.random.randint(0, k)
sys_sample = population[start::k]
print(f"   Every {k}th element starting at {start}")
print(f"   Sample size: {len(sys_sample)}")
print(f"   Sample mean: {np.mean(sys_sample):.1f}")
FULL_CODE_END -->

> âš ï¸ **Warning:** Non-random samples can lead to biased conclusions!

slides.title: Sampling Distribution
slides.content:
# Sampling Distribution ğŸ“ˆ

The distribution of a statistic across many samples.

## Concept

If we repeatedly:
1. Draw a sample from population
2. Calculate a statistic (e.g., mean)
3. Record the value

The distribution of these values is the **sampling distribution**.

## Properties of Sample Mean Distribution

| Property | Formula |
|----------|--------|
| Mean | Î¼_xÌ„ = Î¼ (population mean) |
| Standard Error | SE = Ïƒ / âˆšn |
| Shape | Approximately normal (CLT) |

## Standard Error

The standard deviation of the sampling distribution.

```python
import numpy as np

# Demonstrate sampling distribution
np.random.seed(42)
population = np.random.normal(100, 15, 10000)

sample_means = []
for _ in range(1000):
    sample = np.random.choice(population, 30)
    sample_means.append(np.mean(sample))

print(f"SE (theoretical): {15/np.sqrt(30):.2f}")
print(f"SE (observed): {np.std(sample_means):.2f}")
```

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
import numpy as np

np.random.seed(42)

print("=== Sampling Distribution ===")

# Create population
pop_mean = 100
pop_std = 15
population = np.random.normal(pop_mean, pop_std, 100000)

print(f"\nPopulation: N({pop_mean}, {pop_std})")
print(f"Population size: {len(population)}")

# Generate sampling distribution
print("\nGenerating sampling distributions...")

for n in [10, 30, 100]:
    sample_means = []
    for _ in range(5000):
        sample = np.random.choice(population, n, replace=False)
        sample_means.append(np.mean(sample))
    
    theoretical_se = pop_std / np.sqrt(n)
    observed_se = np.std(sample_means)
    
    print(f"\nSample size n = {n}:")
    print(f"  Mean of sample means: {np.mean(sample_means):.2f}")
    print(f"  Theoretical SE (Ïƒ/âˆšn): {theoretical_se:.2f}")
    print(f"  Observed SE: {observed_se:.2f}")

print("\nğŸ’¡ Notice: As n increases, SE decreases!")
print("   Larger samples give more precise estimates.")
FULL_CODE_END -->

> ğŸ¯ **Key Insight:** Larger samples â†’ Smaller standard error â†’ More precise estimates!

slides.title: Point Estimation
slides.content:
# Point Estimation ğŸ¯

Using sample statistics to estimate population parameters.

## Point Estimators

A single value that estimates a population parameter.

| Parameter | Estimator | Symbol |
|-----------|-----------|--------|
| Population mean (Î¼) | Sample mean | xÌ„ |
| Population variance (ÏƒÂ²) | Sample variance | sÂ² |
| Population proportion (p) | Sample proportion | pÌ‚ |

## Properties of Good Estimators

### 1. Unbiased
Expected value equals the parameter
E[estimator] = parameter

### 2. Consistent
Approaches parameter as n â†’ âˆ

### 3. Efficient
Smallest variance among unbiased estimators

## Example

```python
import numpy as np

# Estimate population mean
sample = [68, 72, 65, 70, 75, 69, 71, 73]
point_estimate = np.mean(sample)
print(f"Point estimate of Î¼: {point_estimate}")
```

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
import numpy as np

np.random.seed(42)

print("=== Point Estimation ===")

# True population (in practice, unknown)
pop_mean = 70
pop_std = 5
population = np.random.normal(pop_mean, pop_std, 10000)

print(f"\nTrue population mean: {pop_mean}")
print(f"True population std: {pop_std}")

# Take samples and estimate
print("\nPoint estimates from different samples:")
for i in range(5):
    sample = np.random.choice(population, 50)
    est_mean = np.mean(sample)
    est_std = np.std(sample, ddof=1)  # ddof=1 for unbiased
    print(f"  Sample {i+1}: Mean = {est_mean:.2f}, Std = {est_std:.2f}")

# Show unbiasedness
print("\n--- Demonstrating Unbiasedness ---")
estimates = [np.mean(np.random.choice(population, 50)) for _ in range(10000)]
print(f"Average of 10,000 sample means: {np.mean(estimates):.2f}")
print(f"True population mean: {pop_mean}")
print("\nğŸ’¡ The average of sample means equals the population mean (unbiased)!")
FULL_CODE_END -->

> âš ï¸ **Limitation:** Point estimates don't tell us about uncertaintyâ€”that's where confidence intervals come in!

slides.title: Confidence Intervals
slides.content:
# Confidence Intervals ğŸ“

Quantifying uncertainty in our estimates.

## Definition

A range of values that likely contains the population parameter.

**95% Confidence Interval:**
"We are 95% confident that the true parameter lies within this range."

## Formula for Mean (known Ïƒ)

CI = xÌ„ Â± z* Ã— (Ïƒ / âˆšn)

| Confidence Level | z* Value |
|-----------------|----------|
| 90% | 1.645 |
| 95% | 1.96 |
| 99% | 2.576 |

## Example

```python
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats

sample = np.array([68, 72, 65, 70, 75, 69, 71, 73, 74, 67])
n = len(sample)
x_bar = np.mean(sample)
se = np.std(sample, ddof=1) / np.sqrt(n)

# 95% CI using t-distribution (unknown Ïƒ)
t_crit = stats.t.ppf(0.975, df=n-1)
ci_lower = x_bar - t_crit * se
ci_upper = x_bar + t_crit * se

print(f"95% CI: ({ci_lower:.2f}, {ci_upper:.2f})")
```

## Interpretation âš ï¸

**Correct:** "95% of intervals constructed this way contain Î¼"

**Incorrect:** "There's a 95% probability Î¼ is in this interval"

> ğŸ¯ **Key Insight:** The parameter is fixed; it's the interval that's random!

slides.title: Confidence Interval Factors
slides.content:
# Factors Affecting CI Width ğŸ“

Understanding what makes intervals wider or narrower.

## The Three Factors

### 1. Sample Size (n)
- â†‘ n â†’ Narrower CI
- SE = Ïƒ/âˆšn decreases with n

### 2. Confidence Level
- â†‘ Confidence â†’ Wider CI
- z* increases with confidence

### 3. Variability (Ïƒ)
- â†‘ Ïƒ â†’ Wider CI
- More variability = more uncertainty

## Comparison

| Factor | Change | Effect on CI |
|--------|--------|-------------|
| n | Increase | Narrower |
| Confidence | Increase | Wider |
| Ïƒ | Increase | Wider |

## Example: Effect of Sample Size

```python
import numpy as np

std = 15
z = 1.96  # 95% confidence

for n in [25, 100, 400, 1600]:
    margin = z * (std / np.sqrt(n))
    print(f"n={n:4}: Margin of Error = Â±{margin:.2f}")
```

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
import numpy as np

print("=== Factors Affecting CI Width ===")

std = 15  # Population standard deviation
mean = 100  # Assume sample mean

# Effect of sample size
print("\n1. EFFECT OF SAMPLE SIZE (95% CI)")
z = 1.96
for n in [25, 100, 400, 1600]:
    margin = z * (std / np.sqrt(n))
    ci = (mean - margin, mean + margin)
    print(f"   n = {n:4}: CI = ({ci[0]:.1f}, {ci[1]:.1f}), Width = {2*margin:.1f}")

# Effect of confidence level
print("\n2. EFFECT OF CONFIDENCE LEVEL (n=100)")
n = 100
confidence_levels = [(0.90, 1.645), (0.95, 1.96), (0.99, 2.576)]
for conf, z_val in confidence_levels:
    margin = z_val * (std / np.sqrt(n))
    ci = (mean - margin, mean + margin)
    print(f"   {conf:.0%}: CI = ({ci[0]:.1f}, {ci[1]:.1f}), Width = {2*margin:.1f}")

# Effect of variability
print("\n3. EFFECT OF VARIABILITY (n=100, 95% CI)")
z = 1.96
n = 100
for std_val in [5, 15, 30, 50]:
    margin = z * (std_val / np.sqrt(n))
    ci = (mean - margin, mean + margin)
    print(f"   Ïƒ = {std_val:2}: CI = ({ci[0]:.1f}, {ci[1]:.1f}), Width = {2*margin:.1f}")

print("\nğŸ’¡ Insight: Increasing sample size is the best way to narrow CI!")
FULL_CODE_END -->

> ğŸ¯ **Best Strategy:** Increase sample size to get narrower intervals without sacrificing confidence!

slides.title: T-Distribution
slides.content:
# The t-Distribution ğŸ“Š

Used when population standard deviation is unknown.

## When to Use t vs z?

| Scenario | Distribution | Reason |
|----------|-------------|--------|
| Ïƒ known, n â‰¥ 30 | z | Standard normal |
| Ïƒ unknown | t | Extra uncertainty |
| Small sample (n < 30) | t | Wider tails |

## Properties of t-Distribution

- Bell-shaped and symmetric
- Heavier tails than normal
- Approaches normal as df â†’ âˆ
- Depends on degrees of freedom (df = n - 1)

## CI with t-Distribution

CI = xÌ„ Â± t* Ã— (s / âˆšn)

Where:
- s = sample standard deviation
- t* = t-critical value for df = n-1

## Example

```python
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats

sample = [23, 25, 28, 22, 26, 24, 27, 25]
n = len(sample)
x_bar = np.mean(sample)
s = np.std(sample, ddof=1)
se = s / np.sqrt(n)

t_crit = stats.t.ppf(0.975, df=n-1)
ci = (x_bar - t_crit * se, x_bar + t_crit * se)
print(f"95% CI: {ci}")
```

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats

print("=== T-Distribution ===")

# Compare t and z distributions
print("\n1. COMPARING T vs Z CRITICAL VALUES (95% CI)")
z_crit = 1.96
print(f"   z-critical (95%): {z_crit:.3f}")

for df in [5, 10, 30, 100, 1000]:
    t_crit = stats.t.ppf(0.975, df=df)
    print(f"   t-critical (df={df:4}): {t_crit:.3f}")

print("\n   Notice: t approaches z as df increases!")

# Practical example
print("\n2. CONFIDENCE INTERVAL EXAMPLE")
sample = np.array([23, 25, 28, 22, 26, 24, 27, 25, 29, 24])
n = len(sample)
x_bar = np.mean(sample)
s = np.std(sample, ddof=1)
se = s / np.sqrt(n)

print(f"   Sample: {sample}")
print(f"   n = {n}")
print(f"   xÌ„ = {x_bar:.2f}")
print(f"   s = {s:.2f}")
print(f"   SE = s/âˆšn = {se:.2f}")

# Calculate CI
t_crit = stats.t.ppf(0.975, df=n-1)
margin = t_crit * se
ci = (x_bar - margin, x_bar + margin)

print(f"\n   t-critical (df={n-1}): {t_crit:.3f}")
print(f"   Margin of error: Â±{margin:.2f}")
print(f"   95% CI: ({ci[0]:.2f}, {ci[1]:.2f})")
FULL_CODE_END -->

> ğŸ’¡ **Rule of Thumb:** Always use t-distribution when Ïƒ is unknown (which is almost always)!

slides.title: CI for Proportions
slides.content:
# Confidence Intervals for Proportions ğŸ“Š

Estimating population proportions.

## Formula

CI = pÌ‚ Â± z* Ã— âˆš(pÌ‚(1-pÌ‚)/n)

Where:
- pÌ‚ = sample proportion = x/n
- n = sample size
- z* = z-critical value

## Conditions

Requires:
- Random sample
- npÌ‚ â‰¥ 10 (at least 10 successes)
- n(1-pÌ‚) â‰¥ 10 (at least 10 failures)

## Example: Election Polling

```python
import numpy as np

# Survey results
n = 1000
supporters = 520
p_hat = supporters / n

# 95% CI
z = 1.96
se = np.sqrt(p_hat * (1 - p_hat) / n)
margin = z * se

ci = (p_hat - margin, p_hat + margin)
print(f"Support: {p_hat:.1%}")
print(f"95% CI: ({ci[0]:.1%}, {ci[1]:.1%})")
```

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
import numpy as np

print("=== Confidence Interval for Proportions ===")

# Election polling example
print("\nEXAMPLE: Election Poll")
n = 1000
supporters = 520
p_hat = supporters / n

print(f"Sample size: {n}")
print(f"Supporters in sample: {supporters}")
print(f"Sample proportion (pÌ‚): {p_hat:.3f} ({p_hat:.1%})")

# Check conditions
print(f"\nConditions check:")
print(f"  npÌ‚ = {n * p_hat:.0f} â‰¥ 10? {n * p_hat >= 10}")
print(f"  n(1-pÌ‚) = {n * (1-p_hat):.0f} â‰¥ 10? {n * (1-p_hat) >= 10}")

# Calculate CI
for conf, z_val in [(0.90, 1.645), (0.95, 1.96), (0.99, 2.576)]:
    se = np.sqrt(p_hat * (1 - p_hat) / n)
    margin = z_val * se
    ci = (p_hat - margin, p_hat + margin)
    print(f"\n{conf:.0%} CI: ({ci[0]:.1%}, {ci[1]:.1%})")
    print(f"   Margin of error: Â±{margin:.1%}")

# Sample size for desired margin
print("\n" + "="*40)
print("\nSample size needed for Â±2% margin (95% CI):")
desired_margin = 0.02
z = 1.96
n_needed = (z**2 * 0.5 * 0.5) / (desired_margin**2)
print(f"  n = {n_needed:.0f}")
FULL_CODE_END -->

> ğŸ¯ **Application:** This is exactly how political polls report "Â±3% margin of error"!

slides.title: Sample Size Determination
slides.content:
# Sample Size Determination ğŸ”¢

How many observations do you need?

## For Estimating a Mean

n = (z* Ã— Ïƒ / E)Â²

Where:
- E = desired margin of error
- Ïƒ = population standard deviation
- z* = critical value for confidence level

## For Estimating a Proportion

n = pÌ‚(1-pÌ‚) Ã— (z*/E)Â²

If pÌ‚ unknown, use pÌ‚ = 0.5 (maximum variance)

## Example Calculations

```python
import numpy as np

# Sample size for mean
sigma = 15
margin = 3
z = 1.96
n_mean = (z * sigma / margin) ** 2
print(f"Sample size for mean: {np.ceil(n_mean):.0f}")

# Sample size for proportion
p = 0.5  # Conservative estimate
margin = 0.03
n_prop = p * (1-p) * (z / margin) ** 2
print(f"Sample size for proportion: {np.ceil(n_prop):.0f}")
```

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
import numpy as np

print("=== Sample Size Determination ===")

# For means
print("\n1. SAMPLE SIZE FOR ESTIMATING A MEAN")
sigma = 15  # Estimated population std
z = 1.96  # 95% confidence

for margin in [5, 3, 2, 1]:
    n = (z * sigma / margin) ** 2
    print(f"   Margin Â±{margin}: n = {np.ceil(n):.0f}")

# For proportions
print("\n2. SAMPLE SIZE FOR ESTIMATING A PROPORTION")
z = 1.96
p = 0.5  # Conservative (maximum variance)

for margin in [0.05, 0.03, 0.02, 0.01]:
    n = p * (1-p) * (z / margin) ** 2
    print(f"   Margin Â±{margin:.0%}: n = {np.ceil(n):.0f}")

print("\n3. EFFECT OF ESTIMATED PROPORTION")
margin = 0.03
for p_est in [0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9]:
    n = p_est * (1-p_est) * (z / margin) ** 2
    print(f"   pÌ‚ = {p_est}: n = {np.ceil(n):.0f}")

print("\nğŸ’¡ Note: p=0.5 gives maximum n (conservative approach)")
FULL_CODE_END -->

> ğŸ’¡ **Pro Tip:** Always round up to ensure sufficient sample size!

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Congratulations! ğŸ‰

You've mastered Inferential Statistics!

## Key Takeaways

### Sampling
- âœ… Population â†’ Sample â†’ Inference
- âœ… Random sampling prevents bias
- âœ… Stratified sampling ensures representation

### Sampling Distribution
- âœ… Distribution of sample statistics
- âœ… Standard Error = Ïƒ/âˆšn
- âœ… Central Limit Theorem: approaches normal

### Estimation
- âœ… **Point Estimate:** Single value (xÌ„)
- âœ… **Interval Estimate:** Range with confidence

### Confidence Intervals

| For | Formula |
|-----|--------|
| Mean (Ïƒ known) | xÌ„ Â± z*(Ïƒ/âˆšn) |
| Mean (Ïƒ unknown) | xÌ„ Â± t*(s/âˆšn) |
| Proportion | pÌ‚ Â± z*âˆš(pÌ‚(1-pÌ‚)/n) |

### CI Interpretation
- âœ… "95% of intervals contain Î¼"
- âœ… Wider CI = More confidence OR smaller n OR more variability

### Sample Size
- âœ… â†‘ sample size â†’ narrower CI
- âœ… Plan ahead for desired precision

> ğŸš€ **Next Steps:** Learn Hypothesis Testing to make data-driven decisions!

You can now quantify uncertainty! ğŸ“Š
